upon Monday withal the Army from Bodman towards Truro, Truro being then the enemies head quarters, and to Tregmon where I quartred that night: Sir Ralph Hopton Å¿ent a Trumpeter to me with a Letter, deÅ¿iring to have CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners appointed on both Å¿ides, to meet at TreÅ¿ilian-Bridge the next day with power to Treat and conclude, which I aÅ¿Å¿ented to: The Treaty accordingly began, the CommiÅ¿sioners meeting about four a clock in the afternoon, and I in the mean time advancing the quarters of the Army to Truro and St. Allan: After Å¿ome time Å¿pent between the CommiÅ¿sioners, this Agreement was made, a copy whereof I have here alÅ¿o incloÅ¿ed, and in execution thereof this day we began to disband the French Brigade under Col. Lapland: To morrow we proceed with three other Brigades, they having nine in all, and Å¿hall endeavour to Å¿horten this work as much as may be. Truly, Sir, this muÅ¿t needs be acknowledged for an admirable mercy from the Å¿ame gracious hand of providence, that hath hitherto gone along with you, that Å¿o conÅ¿iderable a force as this Å¿hould be Å¿o baffled: FirÅ¿t at Torrington, and afterwards Å¿hould put themÅ¿elves as it were into a net; whereby they were neceÅ¿sitated to take terms to the utter ruine of Å¿o great a body of Cavalry, which according to all our information, and the confeÅ¿Å¿ion of our enemies was not leÅ¿Å¿e at the time of the Treaty then four thouÅ¿and five hundred horÅ¿e: The Articles of Agreement will Å¿peak the mercy, and needs no comment; yet I hope I may make this obÅ¿ervation upon them, that hereby not onely Å¿o great a body of Cavalry is broken, but Å¿o many both officers and Å¿ouldiers diÅ¿obliged from taking Arms againÅ¿t you, and

I remain
